page.title: 05Ecology of the White Peak
page.content: The region is characterised by high limestone grasslands rolling gently downwards towards the east and bordered north and south by two dales whose steep sided valleys and clear streams are only visible at close quarters. The altitude of the land, the cool and damp climate, pastoral farming and mining and quarrying both past and present have all combined to provide a unique national landscape. Of immediate note to the outsider is the large variety of mature deciduous trees, rare wild flowers such as cowslip, mountain pansey, lily of the valley and maiden pink and varied wildlife including peregrin falcons, badgers and trout. This year has been particularly wet and the landscape has retained its springlike apparel throughout the summer.
